keyTakeAways: Climate change will add 57 superhot days per year by 2100 under current emissions commitments, a significant but reduced increase from the worst-case scenario of 114 days.
The Paris Climate Agreement has reduced projected warming from 4°C to 2.6°C, cutting the number of superhot days by half.
Since 2015, the world has already experienced 11 additional superhot days on average.
The impact of climate change is highly unequal: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face disproportionate increases in heat exposure.
Panama is projected to face 149 extra superhot days annually, while major polluters like the U.S., China, and India face only 23–30 extra days.
Despite producing 42% of global CO₂ emissions, top polluters experience less than 1% of the additional heat days, highlighting global climate injustice.
Experts warn that this heat inequality could deepen geopolitical tensions between developed and developing nations.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A research organization that studies climate change impacts and performs attribution studies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the lead organization conducting the study on the increase in superhot days due to climate change, providing scientific credibility to the findings.

namedEntities.name: Climate Central
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S.-based climate research group that supports climate science communication and analysis.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It collaborates with World Weather Attribution in the study, contributing expertise in climate modeling and data analysis.

namedEntities.name: Paris Climate Agreement
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international treaty adopted in 2015 to limit global warming and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is central to the study’s argument that current emissions commitments have reduced future warming and superhot days compared to pre-2015 trajectories.

namedEntities.name: Potsdam Climate Institute
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A research institute that studies climate change and sustainability, with a focus on global climate systems.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Its director, Johan Rockstrom, provides an independent expert perspective on the severity of future climate impacts despite reduced warming.

namedEntities.name: Friederike Otto
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A climate scientist at Imperial College London, co-author of the study.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She provides a direct scientific assessment of the human impact of heatwaves, estimating the scale of affected populations as tens of thousands or millions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central estimates that, despite current climate commitments, the planet will face 57 additional superhot days annually by 2100—nearly two months of extreme heat—due to climate change. This represents a significant reduction from the pre-Paris Agreement worst-case scenario of 114 such days, but still poses a severe threat to human health and ecosystems. The findings reveal a stark global imbalance: small, vulnerable island nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa will face massive increases in heat exposure, while the world’s top carbon polluters—such as the U.S., China, and India—experience only a fraction of those impacts. Experts warn that this disparity not only reflects climate injustice but could also fuel geopolitical tensions, underscoring the urgent need for equitable climate action.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
